Posts.Title: Metallic taste

Posts.Content: I was beginning to think it was just me. You have all just described what I am experiencing, well not the pain in my chest but then I haven't had my radio yet, had surgery, just finished chemo and due to have my lymph nodes removed next week. I didn't expect to feel better immediately, everyone warned me it took a while for the chemo to work its way out of your body. But I didn't expect to feel this tired or this stiff. Like Tracey and Susan I can't sit for too long without my joints seizing up, when I get up in the morning I hobble to the loo and feel like a little old lady.... I’m only 51. I recognise the “you look so well, look at those rosy cheeks” I want to say its not rosy cheeks its a hot flush!! Actually I don’t feel unwell but I don’t feel like me either - my knees, hips and back ache. When I mentioned it to the nurse she said I’d feel tired for a minimum of 6 weeks – is a bit optimistic or unrealistic. She seemed surprised or non committal about the joint pain – doh it seems quite common to me. I was quite active before regularly walking, some days I can walk 1.5 miles others I struggle to do Â½ a mile. I try to pace myself, but find it so frustrating when I want to do things and I start it only to find I can’t finish it. Even sitting reading a book is a pain in the ***, because my hips and knees seize. I try to have a mind over matter mentality, but I’m failing because my body isn’t listening.... its either that or I'm being a lazy bugger. But I don't want my life to be defined by undergoing treatment for cancer, I want to make the most of every day and at the moment I can't. Take care all Carol xx

Posts.Title: good news at last

Posts.Content: Hi Janet They are a pain aren't they, because as you say they leave you so tired. I have to admit for me they were worse when I started chemo, am approaching my 4th cycle and I have the occasional night where its a bit like doing the okey cokey with the duvet, one leg in, one leg out. whole body in, whole body out :o)). I have sash windows, so they are a bit draughty anyway - I leave the latch off so a little bit of air gets through, I let the heating go off before I go to bed so the room cools down, I take a cold drink up with me, I sleep on top of the bed with the duvet folded at the bottom so just my feet/legs are under the covers and most of the time that works for me. I find that if I pull the covers up to my neck its worse so if I have the covers on I try to have them no higher than my chest, mind you I don't have to share my bed - I don't count the dog. Have you tried a summer weight quilt tog 4.5? I also found wearing coton jersey pj's with long sleeves helped me, as I could leave the covers off my top half and still be warm. I have read about a pillow that's supposed to help keep you cool - called a chillow I think, but haven't tried one so no idea if they work. I think the article was in Amoena LIfe Mag, which you can view online. You could talk to your oncologist, but I suspect there is not much they can recommend but its worth asking. Hope you have a cool night Take Care Carol x

Posts.Title: Portacath

Posts.Content: Sorry your chemo was cancelled but probabaly the right decision, you don't want any infection if your immunity is going to go down. What chemo are you having? I have just had my last one and when I look back it wasn't that bad, I consider myself very lucky. It does seem daunting at the beginning you are given all this info and told about taking your temperature and what you can and can't eat, and to add to it you know you have about 8 monthly cycles to get through and it seems forever!. But once you start it does fly by, now I'm at the end it seems like yesterday that the consultant was telling me about my treatment plan. It is hard when you have more ahead of you than behind you, and the half way point can be a bit hard but then you are racing to the finish line. I plotted all of my treatments and my end date on my calender and my outlook calender so everytime a reminder came up I could zap it. At a point when I found it hard round about half way - I just wanted to get of the train and a friend suggested thinking of it as a journey with a start point and an end desitation so you could plot it and tickof the destinations. I decided that at half way I was only in York and wanted to get to Scotland.... and now I am there. After my first treatment, my sister picked me up and as her children were late home we all had McD's and I loved it, I had a little nausea but wasn't sick and the tablets dealt with that. I remember thinking - well whats all the fuss about, this is easy - I was whizing round the supermarket at 7.30am the next day - but in the afternoon I was tired. Everyone will tell you the side effects are cumulative, some cycles they are worse that others, so you may need to pace yourself. My Mac nurse suggested keeping a diary of sorts to help you pick up any pattern in side effects, eg upset tummy, nausea although they do give you meds for this; tiredness, changes in your taste buds etc. It does help and to be honest chemo hasn't stopped me doing things, I was at the Christmas Markets in Germany and Bruges during my 2 cycle. I have gone off certain foods and my taste buds are sometimes affected - but it temporary - and worth it to get rid of those little mutant cells. Take care Carol xx
